Posts.Content: swmmom wrote: Hello, Some background info: lumpectomy on left breast in feb 07, completed chemo in july 07, radiation in sept 07. 13 nodes removed. SN+. Under arm was radiated. I have been doing arm exercises regulary and have no limited range of motion. Developed breast edema. surgeon doesn't seem concerned. she said it will get better with time. Breast feels pretty hard, especially the lower part. you can tell I developed fibrous tissue around the lower part of the breast.  A few weeks ago, I started feeling some tingling around the elbow area and my arm started feeling a bit heavy. Oncologist did ultrasound to rule out blood clots and the results were okay. Both my oncologist and breast surgeon didn't  think my arm looked swollen or any different than my other arm.  Just to be sure, I asked for a referral for a Lymphedema therapist. Make long story short, I had my apt with the therapist today.  I asked the therapist if she would be able to tell whether I had lymphedema or not, and she said, " oh, you have lymphedema." At this point, she didn't even see my arm nor did she ask any questions about my symptoms, history, etc.  She just said if your doctor sent you here then you have lymphedema.  She measured both of my arms, didn't tell me what the measurements were and started taping my arm right away. After she was done, I asked her for a massage, and she said she would show me how to do the massage on my next visit.  I also asked her if she could do something to get rid of the hardness on the breast skin, and she said she had no time for the breast today and she would put some kind of foam in my bra on my next visit and that would help the fibrous tissue. What kind of foam is she talking about? Is it uncomfortable to use?   Anyways ladies, needless to say, my arm feels like it is in a cast and feels very uncomfortable. She wrapped me all the way from my shoulders to my knockles even though I have no discomfort or swolling on my hands.  She said I'd have to wear the bandages 23 hours a day. I just want to rip them off off my arm right now, so I can't even imagine wearing them 24/7.  I mean I will absolutely wear the bandages if I have to , but if I don't have lymphedema then I certainly don't want to put myself through the discomfort. When I finally asked her about my measurements, she said my affected arm was 1-2 cm wider than my other arm in three different areas ( around the elbow). 1-2 cm doesn't sound like a big difference to me between two arms and I would like to hear your thoughts on this. I also asked her if I should exercise and she said whatever I can do without feeling pain is fine. Are there any special exercises to minimize the negative effects of lymphedema or any exercises I should avoid?   I was really looking forward to my apt today,but I just didn't get a good feel from my visit. Do you think she should have examined my arm or at least ask me some questions regarding my history and symptoms before bandaging my arm or massage the arm/ breast and show me some exercises to do? Therapist also said that I would need a sleeve after my swolling went down. My arm doesn't even look swollen now.  By the way, I looked at some pictures on the Internet and the sleeve looks so much easier to wear than the bandages. Am I correct on this?   I am sorry, this post is too long, but I feel overwhelmed right now and need some answers. Thank you. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My visit with the therapist swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 03:25PM swmmom wrote: I finally had my LE appointment with the new therapist today and I am glad to say that it went really well. What a difference can a good therapist make!  She took my history, examined my arm and breast, measured my arm, went over the measurements with me and covered all the treatment options with great detail. Since my swelling was minumum (only around the elbow) she said I might get away with just wearing a sleeve when I am active, but suggested that we try the wrapping for about two weeks to bring the swelling down and then get a sleeve. She thought me how to do the massage and wrapping and made sure I knew how to wrap correctly by myself before leaving her office.  She showed me a few exercises to do and encouraged me to use weights that I am comfortable with and also added that I should do belly/diaphram breathing before and after working out. She gave me a whole bunch of handouts and booked another appointment for tomorrow. So all in all, not a bad appointment, eh? I will keep you posted on my future appointments.  Thanks again for all your suggestions and advice.
Posts.Title: My visit with the therapist swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 07:46PM swmmom wrote: Binney, thank you for your lovely respond. I truly appreciate you taking the time to explain everything to me in great details. thank you again, I feel so much better knowing that my therapist did everything right. They scheduled me with a different therapist for my next apt, not my choice, it is a very busy rehab center. I am hoping to have a better chemistry with the next therapist. I was  a good girl and didn't take off the bandages last night. They feel a lot loser this morning. Is this normal? I don't want to dare to take them off and rewrap b/c I don't know if I could wrap the arm by myself. But I have to take it off at some point, right? Or I would be walking around smellling pretty nasty! One question: If the swelling comes down and my measurements improve, does that mean I will be done with the treatments or does my arm have to be wrapped from now on? Binny, as for my screen name, I don't even know how to swim! My 12 year old daughter is a competitive swimmer and she is quite good at it too.  I told her she would have to teach me how to swim and she said it would cost me.   I was a personal fitness trainer before my diagnosis. As you can imagine, I was very fit and in shape. Not any more though! Thanks to chemo and Arimidex, I am 30 pounds heavier. I was pretty emotional yesterday. I couldn't stop crying. I felt handicapped and l felt like I couldn't do anything with the wrap.  I am feeling a lot better this morning though, which reminds me it is time to wash the sink full of dishes.  Thanks again for your response and have a great weekend.
Posts.Title: My visit with the therapist swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 09:26PM swmmom wrote: Binney, Thanks for the pep talk. It doesn't take much to make me cry and I got all teary-eyed reading your nice response.   My next apt is not until June 2nd. They tried but couldn't get me in any sooner.   When I told the therapist about my hesitance to wrap the arm by myself, she assured me that there was nothing to it and my 12 year old could help me.  I am glad you told me how important it is to wrap it correctly.  I am planning on calling the therapist today to see if I could come in on Monday so that she can wrap my arm again and teach me how to do it. I totally agree with you, a water aerobics class would be a more economical way to go than the "private" swim lessons!  She also said that there are no cost negotiations. She is a little stinker!
Posts.Title: My visit with the therapist swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: May 20, 2008 12:46AM swmmom wrote: Swimangel and Binney, after thinking this thoroughly, I decided to cancel my 9 am appointment this morning. She was going to wrap the arm without a massage like she did at my last appointment. I didn't want to go through that again since my arm started feeling a lot worst than it did before.  I see a little too many red flags with this therapist,  wrapping before massaging(now that I think of it, I am not even sure if the arm was wrapped correctly), no physical exam, no exercise suggestions, couldn't see me again before June, and then it was only going to be once a week for 4 sessions with her assistant.  Make long story short,  I requested a new referral from my PCM and made an appointment with a LE certified P.T near where I live, only 20 minutes away. They booked me for a 2 hour slot.  I will let you know how my new appointment goes. It is on May 28th. Thanks for all of your responses and advice. I truly appreciate it.
Posts.Title: My visit with the therapist swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: May 19, 2008 07:08AM swmmom wrote: Binney, The bandages on my arm became really loose along with the  masking tape that was holding the bandages together. I don't know if it is because I made a mistake by exercising over an hour on the treadmill with loose and tangly bandages on my arm, but my arm definitely feels heavier now than it did before the therapist wrapped the arm. I called her and she said can squeze me in on Monday morning at 9 am to wrap the arm again. What is your opinion on wrapping the arm without doing the massage? Should I not let her do it? Also, is it okay to do cardio with the bandages on, how about light weight lifting? Thanks again for your advice.
Posts.Title: My visit with the therapist swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 08:05PM swmmom wrote: I am going to see her tomorrow and I believe she will do the massage at tomorrow's appointment. She will see me 3 times a week.  I have military health insurance. I pay $12.00 copay and my insurance picks up the rest.
Posts.Title: My visit with the therapist swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: swmmom wrote: Does anyone do skin brushing to sitimulate lymph flow as a part of their LE therapy regimen? If so, any success stories?   Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: skin brushing swmmom Maire67

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 06:52AM swmmom wrote: Hi Binney, Things are going well. I finally found a sleeve that fits and I actually like the way it feels on my arm. It's a soft Juzo-much better than the "miserable Medi" sleeve I was in. Shopping for a sleeve was worst than shopping for a bra! To answer your question, no, my therapist doesn't use a brush. I read about it in a book and did not know if it was okay for LE patients.  I will see my therapist on Monday and will ask her about it as well.
Posts.Title: skin brushing swmmom Maire67

Posts.Content: swmmom wrote: I am recovering from another bout of cellulitis, this time my breast. I was given 3 doses of  IV antiboitic therapy and was sent home with oral antiboitic( doxycycline) for 10 days. today is day four on  Doxycycline and I feel miserable. I have severe case of flu like symptoms all through my body.  I did a little research on this med and found that many people experience the same side effects. Has anyone been on this med and experienced these horrible side effects as I have been?  Last time I had cellulitis on my arm, I was given 3 full days of IV antiboitics followed by Keflex for 10 days, and never had any problems. Since redness on the brest disapperaed after second dose of vancomycin, they stopped the IV after my third dose and switched me to doxycyline.   I will call my surgeon today to see if she can switch me to a different antiboitic because I honestly can't function feeling like this.  Okay, feeling exhausted. gotta get back to bed. I didn't sleep a wink last night.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Doxycyline for cellulitis swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2009 08:50AM swmmom wrote: I called my doctor this morning. She's on vacation.  Her nurse called me back and said that antibotics do not cause flu like symptoms. she also added that if I am feeling sick, I must have the flu.  the redness is gone but my breast still feels slightly warm to touch. Last time I had cellulitis on my arm, they kept me in the hosptial for three full days. This time I was in the hospital for one and a half days and was given 3 doses of antibotics via IV.  Perhaps that wasn't enough.  Any of you know what the standard IV treatment is for cellulitis?   I told the nurse I was feeling miserable and should be checked. She said she will let the fellow on call know.  So I am waiting for the fellow to call me back. Thanks for your responses.
Posts.Title: Doxycyline for cellulitis swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 09:36AM swmmom wrote: Otter, that is one exceptional LE therapist! I wish I could say the same. I had a one hour time slot when I made the apt, but the entire hour only included wrapping and taking measurements, and oh, listening to her talk about how smart her daughter is!
Posts.Title: Don't have LE--therapy consult anyway? otter NancyD

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 08:48AM swmmom wrote: add me to the list of my arm looks worst after the therapy.  My affected arm was less than 2cm larger than my other arm in only one area.  I regret starting therapy. Just because my arm was slightly larger than my other arm didn't mean I had Lymphedema. I thought starting therapy early would reverse the situation, but I really should have just waited and kept an eye on my arm.  My sleeve caused me to gain 2 inches on my upper arm, which was never swollen before. My index finger also started to swell after the therapy, which also was normal before the therapy. I have a thick crease mark inside of my elbow from bandages and it is not going away.  I think if you have very mild swelling in your arm and  it is not visible to the naked eye, you might be better off waiting and keeping an eye on things. Some changes are on the affected arm are normal as a result of surgery, chemo, radiation. etc not becaused your lymphatic system is totally impaired.  I am now only using elevation and mild arm exercises as therapy and my arm actually looks better. I understand everyone's situation is different and therapy can be beneficial for many, but in my situation it was not.
Posts.Title: Deep indentations/marks with REID SLEEVE badboob67 Binney4

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 03:07PM swmmom wrote: Spent most of the afternoon in the hospital. To make long story short, they did an ultrasound of the breast to make sure there were no pockets of pus and anything suspicious. The results were negative. They finally agreed that doxycycline wasn't working and that the cellulitis was waiting to come back. They switched my antiboitic. I will be on keflex for 10 more days. Hopefully that will do the trick. I've been off doxyc for 24 hours and already feeling better. I just could not tolerate the side effects of this drug.      Binney, I told you LE Gods hate me.  Even though I am extra careful to avoid infection, I still come down with it!
Posts.Title: Doxycyline for cellulitis swmmom swmmom

Posts.Content: swmmom wrote: Today is the day! As of today I am a 5 year cancer survivor, and it sure feels good!! I was diagnosed at age 47 with stage 2B IDC. I am still here, alive and doing well. I hope this gives all going through faith that you can make it too. Here's to many more years of being cancer free!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 5 year survivor swmmom shells43

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 11:42AM swmmom wrote: Thank you everyone.  Sanbar8771, our path reports are very similiar. In addition, I've had extensive vascular invasion. You too will reach the 5 year mark. Best of luck! !
Posts.Title: 5 year survivor swmmom shells43

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 11:45AM swmmom wrote: At the risk of sounding cliche, I will say this: when I look out my window and see the beutiful 10 year old girl riding her bike with a huge smile on her face despite losing her courageous battle to neuroblastoma, when my daughter tells me her 13 year old schoolmate is losing his leg to a rare form of bone cancer,  I look at my wraps on the floor in a tangled mess and  say  to myself, what a small price to pay for being alive!
Posts.Title: SO, HOW DO YOU COPE???!!! Binney4 sisterinspirit

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 06:30PM swmmom wrote: Thanks again everyone. At first I was really hesitant to even post a message as I didn't want to jinx anything, but it makes me very happy that I've gladdened some hearts today.  Christina19 and Jenlee, the fear of recurrance really gets better, I promise! I don't plan on any recurrances and you ladies shouldn't either!  Sflow, I am actually afraid to get off the Arimidex. I tolerate it really well and take great comfort in knowing that it's providing me with great protection. I hope my oncologist agrees with me when I see him in 2 months and renews my prescription.
Posts.Title: 5 year survivor swmmom shells43

Posts.Content: swmmom wrote: I completed radiation treatments in Sept '07 with no problems and about a month ago, I started hearing crackling sounds coming from my left lung. They did a chest CT and it showed radiation induced pneumonitis. My doctor said since I have no coughing and my symptoms are mild, he will let it run its course. I guess it is reversible.  I don't know if I feel comfortable about not getting treated for it since my wheezing is getting worst. I definetely don't want to it progress to lung fibrosis. I should also mention that I am a non-smoker. Has anyone experienced this or am I one of the few lucky ones to get this pneumonitis crap?   Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lung injury swmmom GardenGirl65

Posts.Content: swmmom wrote: After two weeks of wrapping, I finally got a prescription for a 20-30 mmHg compression sleeve.  I went to a very reputable medical store here in St louis and the lady who measured my arm gave me one off the shelf. It is a Jobst brand, size medium sleeve with slicone border. The sleeve is very comfortable and it sure beats the wraps, but the slicone part of the sleeve is extremely tight and cuts through my skin around my upper and under arm.  It really hurts, so I quit wearing it.  I also think  that the length of the sleeve is too long. It comes all the way up to my shoulders. Is this how it is supposed to feel or do you think I was not given the right size of sleeve and might need a custom fit sleeve?  I mean I thought we were supposed to avoid tight/constricted clothing on the affected arm not to worsen our already comprised circulatory system. The upper part of the sleeve was beyond tight. It left a huge red mark on my skin. My next appointment with the therapist is on Monday and I will take the sleeve with me for her to see, but I wanted to get your opinions in the mean time.  Thanks in advance, Dee  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: sleeve dilemma swmmom GoodMommy

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 06:32PM swmmom wrote: Chris, I got my sleeve from Medical West on Brentwood, near Galleria. It cost me $70.00, but you can get the same sleeve on the Internet for a lot less. Dee
Posts.Title: sleeve dilemma swmmom GoodMommy
